content.description: This is the obvious wide crack on the right side of the north face of the dome. The crack is split up by a ledge. From the ledge, either continue climbing straight up the crack to the top of the dome (and walk off), OR take a slightly runout ramp up left to an anchor and rappel.This is a great wide crack to test your offwidth skills on! Enough face holds exist that you don't really need to climb wide! But you should try, cause why else are you on an offwidth?
content.protection:
Bust out that big gear! 

  1 X #0.5- #2. #5, #6   2 X #3 - #4   A large nut would come in handy protecting the moves on the ramp to the anchors 

  Chain anchors
content.location: Look for the huge obvious crack reaching all the way to the ground.

content.description: This is the high line of bolts on the face between the two obvious crack systems.Well, it's almost a sport route! You'll have to start on one of the two cracks on either side and wander over to the bolts which appear about 25 feet up. The climbing on the face is actually quite sustained and engaging. A myriad of small face holds give just the faintest hint of a path through the seemingly empty face.
content.protection:
Bring a few cams for the first 25 feet, depending on which crack you start from (if you start on the wide crack, definitely bring the #6!)   5 Bolts 

  Rappel Anchors
content.location: The bolts start 25 feet directly above the start of the arching crack.Â

content.description: Amazing! This wild crack doesn't quite reach the ground, puzzling through the first moves to get established in the crack system could arguably be the crux. Ride the crack as it starts leaning sharply left, traversing to the edge of a corner. Going around the corner will present you with an interesting dilemma: hand traverse or foot traverse...you decide!? Around the corner in an alcove, the crack jolts away from its bend and shoots straight as an arrow slightly right to the anchors above. The upper crack is truly amazing splitter hand jams on perfect, flawless rock. Get on this gem.
content.location: Look for the small tree underneath the crack, which starts about 10 feet off the ground. If the crack above you arcs left, you're there.

content.description: This small dome is seen a short ways off on the right side of the road as you're driving through the clunky streambed after Isle of You. Though the chossy looking buttress facing the road looks less than ideal, the out-of-sight north face has some stellar climbs hiding in plain sight. A great place to practice some Cochise crack climbing, or to beat the heat (and the crowds!) at Isle of You.
